comments:
Build ID: 2.2.2.v200612211127

Steps To Reproduce:
We have an EMF model, and some code to use it that has suddenly broken in Eclipse 3.2.2 (*.emf.ecore_2.2.2.v200612211127).
This model & code have worked fine on various builds / releases since 3.2.0.

Here is the error:
	java.lang.RuntimeException: Invalid entry feature 'ComponentTree.abstractComponentDefinition'
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.util.BasicFeatureMap.validate(BasicFeatureMap.java:86)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.util.BasicFeatureMap.addUnique(BasicFeatureMap.java:1383)
	at org.eclipse.emf.common.util.BasicEList.add(BasicEList.java:600)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.util.BasicFeatureMap.doAdd(BasicFeatureMap.java:505)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.util.BasicFeatureMap.add(BasicFeatureMap.java:1131)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.util.FeatureMapUtil$FeatureEList.add(FeatureMapUtil.java:646)
	at com.ibm.rcp.aaf.emc.EditModeController.setWires(EditModeController.java:1034)

I can provide a project that contains the Model, and some code to invoke the error, but I cannot post it here.

More information:

There isn't much we can do with the information provided in this bugzilla so I am returning it as invalid.  We need a description of how to reproduce the problem or, even better, a simple test case that shows what is going on.

Based on the stack trace you've provided, I am guessing this is related with https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=166838.

If that's the case, this is probably a problem in your application that has never been detected before.  There is an easy test you can do to verify this: using a build that "works", replace the call to FeatureMap.add(object) by FeatureMap.add(0, object).  If you also get the exception, we would know you are trying to append an invalid object.
Please take a look at the bug Marcelo referenced. If that's not the issue, feel free to send your test case to Marcelo or me if you can't post it here.

Created an attachment (id=56921)
Here is a small plugin (with source) containing the model, and a some test code to invoke the exception.

When you run the plugin, you will see a TestEMF menuitem that you can use to launch a dialog, that will run the code that causes the problem.

The model is IBM Confidential, so I could not post it along with the bug in Bugzilla.
This model, and similar code using it has been in use, and has worked since Eclipse 3.2.0.

Regards,
	Brian O'Gorman
